Context:
The Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management offers a Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program with a focus on areas such as construction planning, project management, site superintendancy, estimating, budget and bid preparation, sustainable building science, and engineering studies. Students who enroll in the program in January are required to complete semester 2 in the summer (May to August) of the same year to continue into semester 3 in the fall.

Field education and experiential learning options can be obtained by contacting the Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management for updated information. A co-op stream following semester four is anticipated to be offered with selective entry, check with the school for more details.

The construction industry in Ontario and the GTA generates over 360,000 on-site and off-site jobs, pays over $22 billion in wages, and creates almost $43 billion in Ontario’s built environment. The expanding regional transit network and population demographic shifts have led to high demand for housing and significant construction activity.

Pathways to the Construction Management degree program are available after completing the three-year Construction Engineering Technology program with a minimum GPA of 3.0. For more information, see the Transfer Guide.

The required courses for semester 1 include BLDG 1025 - Surveying for Construction Technology, BLDG 1126 - Print and Specifications Reading for Construction Technology 1, and BLDG 1127 - Construction Management. Please note that the program is undergoing current review, and courses after year 1 are expected to change in the 2023-24 year.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Construction Engineering Technology Program T105 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides a list of courses offered by the college during six semesters in various buildings (BLDG) with their respective codes and names. Some courses have specific prerequisites or are part of a sequence, such as Mathematics for Construction Technology 1 and 2 (MATH 1140 and MATH 1150), Construction Estimating 1 and 2 (BLDG 1129 and BLDG 1136), and Mechanics of Materials 1 – Statics and 2 – Strength of Materials (BLDG 2061 and BLDG 2065).

Additionally, there are courses related to Construction Management (Introduction and Overview, Planning and Scheduling, Contract and Document Administration), Print and Specifications Reading for Construction Technology (available in both semesters 1 and 3), Communicating Across Contexts and Professional Communications for Building Technologies (COMM 2000 and COMM 1113), and a General Education Elective.

There are also courses related to safety, such as Construction Health and Safety (BLDG 1077) and Workplace Skills for Construction Technology (BLDG 2068). Furthermore, students will learn about Building Science (BLDG 1165), Construction Materials and Methods (BLDG 1042 and BLDG 1145), and various construction technologies like AutoCad (BLDG 1128) and Revit (BLDG 1078).

Lastly, students will study Construction Law (BLDG 2090), Building Codes (BLDG 1076 and BLDG 2076), MEP Systems (BLDG 2046), Construction Pricing (BLDG 3004), Construction Management 3 – Site Operations (BLDG 2045), Structures 1 – Timber and Steel (BLDG 3048), and Sustainable Building Practices (BLDG 3077).

There is no mention of any specific program offered by the college in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Construction Engineering Technology Program T105 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program Offered: Construction Engineering
Courses:
- BLDG 3019: Construction Management 5 – Cost and Schedule Control
- BLDG 3020: BIM for Construction Technology
- BLDG 3058: Structures 2 – Concrete
- BLDG 3059: Entrepreneurship
- BLDG 3061: Technical Thesis 2
- BLDG 3065: Construction Accounting
- BLDG 3082: Business Fundamentals
Mandatory Course: COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000, charged extra
General Education Electives
Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Develop and use strategies to enhance professional growth and ongoing learning in the construction engineering field.
2. Comply with workplace health and safety practices and procedures in accordance with current legislation and regulations.
3. Complete duties and assist in monitoring that work is performed in compliance with contractual obligations, applicable laws, standards, bylaws, codes and ethical practices in the construction engineering field.
4. Promote and carry out sustainability practices in accordance with contract documents, industry standards and environmental legislative requirements.
5. Facilitate collaboration and interaction among project stakeholders to support construction engineering projects.
6. Collect, process, analyze and coordinate technical data to produce written and graphical project-related documents.
7. Coordinate and facilitate the collecting, processing, interpreting and application of survey/geomatics and layout information to implement construction projects.
8. Select and use industry-specific electronic and digital technologies to support the design and construction of projects.
9. Analyze and solve technical problems related to the design and implementation of construction projects by applying engineering concepts, technical mathematics and building science.
10. Schedule, coordinate and monitor the progression of construction projects by applying principles of construction project management.
11. Prepare estimates of time, cost, quality and quantity, tenders and bids.
12. Perform, coordinate and facilitate quality control testing and monitoring of equipment, materials and methods involved in the implementation and completion of construction projects.
13. Apply teamwork, leadership, supervision and interpersonal skills when working individually or within multidisciplinary teams to complete work on construction projects.
Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $3,928.00
- International Tuition: $17,545.00
Additional Costs: N/A

Context:
The text provides information about the tuition fees for programs starting in Fall 2022 and Fall 2023 at George Brown College. Here is the extracted information:

* Tuition fees for programs starting in Fall 2022: $17,545.00 for the first two semesters
* Tuition fees for programs starting in Fall 2023: Total fees are listed, but no specific amount is given
* OSAP funding is available for this program, subject to applicant meeting eligibility criteria
* Admission requirements include Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits.
* Course exemptions are available based on college or university credits, and information can be found in the Transfer Guide.
* International students should visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.
* Laptop and Internet specifications are recommended for students: Windows 10 Home 64-bit English, 9th Generation Intel Core i7-9750H (12MB Cache), and home Internet service with 25 to 40 Mbps and a ping time of 20–100 ms.
